awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Plasma Physics of Neutron Star Mergers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial support for a Workshop on Plasma Physics of Neutron Star Mergers scheduled to take place on October 1-3, 2018 at the Center for Computational Astrophysics of the Flatiron Institute in New York City, NY. This workshop will bring together experts in gravitational wave astrophysics and plasma physics to discuss key problems at the interface between these two traditionally disconnected fields, identify "grand challenge" problems, and identify areas where significant progress could be made in the next 5-10 years.  It is anticipated that substantial progress in addressing these scientific challenges will entail significant computational resources and new methodologies, so it is fitting that the Center for Computational Astrophysics has expressed interest in hosting the workshop.

The merger of neutron stars GW170817 has been the best observed astronomical event in recorded history, with LIGO detection triggering successful observations by 70 teams working in the gamma ray, x-ray, UV, optical, and radio bands. Close to 150 preprints dedicated to the merger appeared on the arXiv during the two days after the publication of the LIGO result in October 2017. The workshop is an opportunity to bring into this field the plasma physicists and magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) experts that have the expertise to understand the plasma/MHD phenomena that are crucial for generating the fireworks in the whole of the electromagnetic spectrum.  It is expected that the workshop will have a large impact on both the plasma physics research and on the multi-messenger astrophysics of neutron star mergers.  The outcome will include improved understanding of the environment for heavy element nucleosynthesis, which has been shown to be crucial for the chemical evolution of galaxies, and key input for design of future astronomical facilities and missions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award supported a workshop "Plasma Physics of Netron Star Mergers" that took place at Flatiron Institute in New York over the course of 3 days, October 1-3 in 2018. The workshop was a great success.


 

In August 2017 the astrophysics world was shaken up by the discovery of a merger of 2 neutron stars, that became the best observed astronomical event in recorded history. Over 70 teams took part in the observations and analysis of gravitational waves, radio waves, infrared, optical and ultra-violet light, x-rays, and gamma rays generated by the merger. Countless teams contributed to theoretical interpretation of these signals. However, the astrophysical theorists trying to explain the signals quickly realized that they needed input from plasma physics in order to create reliable models. Enter the NSF-funded workshop funded by this award (PI Levin), where the invited participants included  both astrophysics and plasma physics theorists. Several observational astronomers were also present, to insure that the theorists were aware of the most up-to-date measurements. Dr. Vyacheslav Lukin was the NSF representative at the meeting, and on top of learning first-hand what the scientists were thinking about, he gave a presentation on research opportunities in this field that will be supported by the NSF in the near future.
The presentations included some background lectures, necessary when two somewhat disparate communities take part in the meeting, but mostly concentrated on frontier research. Plenty of time was left for the discussions, and the third day was fully in the discussion format. 
The culmination of the discussion was formulating a list of Grand Challenge problems, more precisely the set of issues that have to be explored at the interface between astrophysics and plasma physics, in order to understand what exactly happened during the neutron star merger observed 2 years ago. Solving these will help create models of mergers that will be tested over the next decade by upcoming observations of other neutron star mergers.  The picture attached to this report shows the final discussion session, conducted by Eliot Quataert and Yuri Levin (the PI) during which the grand challenge questions were formulated.
